title: Under California System 2 bankruptcy exemptions (703,) is there a specific code for IRAs?
question: I have an individual rollover IRA which I opened after I lost my job. I do not see any exemption code for that under the 703 codes in California.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Estates,Inherited Roth IRA and estate planning,Estate property
answers:
To exempt IRAs, every person that files for relief under the bankruptcy code can use 11 USC ยง 522(b)(c)(3) which states that the following retirement plans are exempt: "(C) retirement funds to the extent that those funds are in a fund or account that is exempt from taxation under section 401, 403, 408, 408A, 414, 457, or 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986."

Section 408 covers IRAs.

However, I agree with Mr. Granvold on why filing for relief under the bankruptcy code pro se is a mistake a large percentage of the time. Per a report issued by the US Courts in 2011, the survey that was performed found that pro se chapter 7 cases were dismissed 8 times as often as chapter 7 cases that were filed with attorney representation. The study also found that attorney represented chapter 13 cases result in a confirmed play 55 times more often that pro se chapter 13 cases.

An experienced bankruptcy attorney that practices before the judge and trustee that will be assigned to your filing will know how these matters are handled and what you need to do to protect your assets and will also understand other issues such as the timing of the filing of your case.

We see pro se bankruptcy filers on this forum every week that are asking questions about how to extricate themselves from the mess that they are in. Some are about to lose some of their assets or spend a substantial amount of money to correct the problem because they did something wrong or failed to understand why the asset would be taken by the chapter 7 trustee. Many times those filers are going to spend much more than those debtors would have paid a lawyer to do thing right the first time.

You can search for an attorney using the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page.

Do you own a home? Do you have equity in the home?
Do you own other real estate? Do you have equity in it?
What other assets do you have?
Is your income above or below the median for your family size?
The anser to those questions and others will help determine which set of exemptions to use.
Hire an attorney to help you.

The first mistake you are making ALL of us attorneys will tell you: you need to employ an experienced attorney. Too many issues and assets and results are at stake! Thus, I will point out some of those for you next . For example NO attorney can tell you what exemption is available w/o knowing where you have lived in the last 2 years in fact!

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
